articles.headline: China Considers Offering Aid in Europe’s Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Wen Jiabao said China might be willing to help finance Europe’s stabilization by working with the International Monetary Fund.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Wen Jiabao said China might be willing to help finance Europe’s stabilization by working with the International Monetary Fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Prime Minister Wen Jiabao said Thursday that China would consider working with the International Monetary Fund to help shore up Europe’s finances. But he left unclear whether China was willing to drop conditions that so far have made its proposed help unappealing to European nations.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Effort to Rebrand Arab Spring Backfires in Iran
articles.snippet: Iran invited young activists to Tehran for a conference on the “Islamic Awakening,” but the fact that no one from Syria’s opposition was invited disrupted the whole script.
articles.abstract: Iran invited young activists to Tehran for a conference on the “Islamic Awakening,” but the fact that no one from Syria’s opposition was invited disrupted the whole script.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — It was meant to be a crowning moment in which Iran put its own Islamic stamp on the Arab Spring. More than a thousand young activists were flown here earlier this week (at government expense) for a conference on “the Islamic Awakening,” Tehran’s effort to rebrand the popular Arab uprisings of the past year.

articles.headline: Brutal Crimes Grip an Indian Reservation
articles.snippet: On a huge stretch of scrubland in central Wyoming, a two-year federal crime-fighting initiative has made little difference.
articles.abstract: On a huge stretch of scrubland in central Wyoming, a two-year federal crime-fighting initiative has made little difference.
articles.lead_paragraph: WIND RIVER INDIAN RESERVATION, Wyo. — At a boys’ basketball game here last month, Wyoming Indian High School, a perennial state power, was trading baskets with a local rival. The players, long-limbed and athletic, are among the area’s undisputed stars, and their games one of its few diversions. On this night, more than 2,500 cheering, stomping people came to watch.

articles.headline: In a Focus on Gold, History Repeats Itself
articles.snippet: Newt Gingrich’s call for a commission to examine a return to the gold standard has a familiar ring. Ronald Reagan did the same more than 30 years ago.
articles.abstract: Newt Gingrich’s call for a commission to examine a return to the gold standard has a familiar ring. Ronald Reagan did the same more than 30 years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: As it was in 1980, could it be again in 2012?

articles.headline: White House Offers Plan to Lure Jobs to America
articles.snippet: Rising wages in developing countries and other factors have made keeping manufacturing work in the United States a much more viable option, the Obama administration argues.
articles.abstract: Rising wages in developing countries and other factors have made keeping manufacturing work in the United States a much more viable option, the Obama administration argues.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his State of the Union address, President Obama called for a wide-ranging package of policies to help create American manufacturing jobs, including trade enforcement measures, business tax breaks and worker training programs.

articles.headline: Army Studies Workout Supplements After Deaths
articles.snippet: The military has removed dietary supplements containing the ingredient dimethylamylamine from stores on its bases, though the products are widely available elsewhere in the country.
articles.abstract: The military has removed dietary supplements containing the ingredient dimethylamylamine from stores on its bases, though the products are widely available elsewhere in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States Army is investigating whether certain dietary supplements for athletes, available until recently at stores on military bases in the United States, may have played a role in the deaths of two soldiers.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: Zuckerberg Remains the Undisputed Boss at Facebook
articles.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg’s success is a lesson in what works in Silicon Valley: Stay in charge, stave off potential predators and expand the company so quickly that no one can challenge the boss.
articles.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg’s success is a lesson in what works in Silicon Valley: Stay in charge, stave off potential predators and expand the company so quickly that no one can challenge the boss.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the moment he dropped out of Harvard University, Mark Zuckerberg has stayed remarkably focused on two things: Facebook, and being the boss of Facebook.

articles.headline: Before the Toss, Super Bowl Ads
articles.snippet: Advertisers placed many Super Bowl spots on YouTube or social media well ahead of the game, hoping to start a conversation and generate follow-up interest.
articles.abstract: Advertisers placed many Super Bowl spots on YouTube or social media well ahead of the game, hoping to start a conversation and generate follow-up interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl has long been the biggest day of the year for advertising, as more than 100 million Americans watch television’s most expensive and daring commercials. Unlike years past, one thing will be mostly missing this year: surprise.

articles.headline: To Fix Image, Republicans in House Think Small
articles.snippet: Unpopular and divided, the once mighty House Republicans are laboring to repair their image and frame a new agenda.
articles.abstract: Unpopular and divided, the once mighty House Republicans are laboring to repair their image and frame a new agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Unpopular and divided, the once mighty House Republicans are laboring to repair their image and frame a new agenda.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Outcry Is Fierce to Cut in Funds by Cancer Group
articles.snippet: The Susan G. Komen for the Cure foundation was faced with dissension in its own ranks and roiling anger online over its decision to end its long partnership with Planned Parenthood.
articles.abstract: The Susan G. Komen for the Cure foundation was faced with dissension in its own ranks and roiling anger online over its decision to end its long partnership with Planned Parenthood.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s leading breast cancer advocacy organization confronted the growing furor Thursday over its decision to largely end its decades-long partnership with Planned Parenthood, with rising dissension in its own ranks and a roiling anger on the Internet showing the power of social media to harness protest.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Preston and Gardiner Harris

articles.headline: S.E.C. Is Avoiding Tough Sanctions for Large Banks
articles.snippet: Even as the Securities and Exchange Commission has stepped up its investigations of Wall Street, the agency has repeatedly allowed the biggest firms to avoid punishments.
articles.abstract: Even as the Securities and Exchange Commission has stepped up its investigations of Wall Street, the agency has repeatedly allowed the biggest firms to avoid punishments.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as the Securities and Exchange Commission has stepped up its investigations of Wall Street in the last decade, the agency has repeatedly allowed the biggest firms to avoid punishments specifically meant to apply to fraud cases.

articles.headline: Job Gains Reflect Hope a Recovery Is Blooming
articles.snippet: The front wheels have lifted off the runway. Now, Americans are waiting to see if the economy can truly get aloft.
articles.abstract: The front wheels have lifted off the runway. Now, Americans are waiting to see if the economy can truly get aloft.
articles.lead_paragraph: The front wheels have lifted off the runway. Now, Americans are waiting to see if the economy can truly get aloft.

articles.headline: 3-Year High for the Dow as Wall St. Cheers Data
articles.snippet: The Dow industrials closed at the highest point since 2008, and the Nasdaq composite regained a level last seen in 2000.
articles.abstract: The Dow industrials closed at the highest point since 2008, and the Nasdaq composite regained a level last seen in 2000.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was just what the stock market needed. When one of the most closely watched data reports showed a generally strong picture of the United States economy on Friday, stocks on Wall Street picked right up and surged throughout the day, sending the Dow to its best closing level since 2008.

articles.headline: At 102%, His Tax Rate Takes the Cake
articles.snippet: In submissions of tax burdens from readers, James Ross, founder and managing member of the investment firm Rossrock, was on a perch all his own.
articles.abstract: In submissions of tax burdens from readers, James Ross, founder and managing member of the investment firm Rossrock, was on a perch all his own.
